body: Generally looks good. Please remove *_v1 in front end and add more tests.

in mxnet0.9.5. even the gradient seems to be normal, the training still can not converge. so I think the gradient is still not right in any condition of two.
but the same training can converge fast in mxnet0.8.0.
hoping the training is going to be ok after you fixed the bug.

Does anyone have pretrained inception-rensnet-v2 model pretrained on ImageNet or other general dataSet? Thanks a lot!

use the following initialization of data will give the stable output:
```
arg_dict['data'][:] = np.asarray(range(np.prod(data_shape)), dtype=np.float32).reshape(data_shape)/np.prod(data_shape)
```
and, I compared the 0.9.5 with 0.8.0:
let ```grad_req['proxy_yM'] = 'write'```, two version will give same result gradient info.
let ```grad_req['proxy_yM'] = 'null'```, 0,9.5 changed, but 0.8.0 retained same.

@piiswrong  I occurs this issue when inference. Does this mean MXNet only can use one gpu when inference because of this code below? Can MXNet make inference use multi-gpus?
```Python
mod.forward(Batch([mx.nd.array(img)]))
```
It seems need to use mxnet.dataiter, to infer based on batch (multi-gpus)?

Works out-of-the-box now for me.

I've gone through the Python Basics docs and fixed some typos/grammar issues.  I did my best to stay true to the issue and fix only obvious typos and grammar issues.  There is still more work to do in terms of fixing sentences and paragraphs, but that can be done in a separate pull request.

Please review and merge.

@starimpact Thanks for the info. I am working on something else of high priority. I will start on this issue once it's done.

Alright I figured out why it does not work: I had MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR set to 1. I disabled it and now the networks converge on decent values and actually produce different predictions. Hope this was the root of the problem.

Hi, 
Can you please tell me how exactly you disabled the MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR?

Some kind of example with a code will be really helpful.
Thanks

I have some other interesting findings.  On GPU, input size 330x**334**x3 takes 7.7ms, where as size 330x**335**x3 takes 34ms.  Dose anyone encounter such strange phenomena?
PS:  I have tested the same net using Caffe, things gonna be OK. The time consumption is reasonable and  increases along with the increasing input size.
I  tested on TITAN X(Pascal), the same problem remains.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6196

Hey,

Just set the environmental variable MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR to 0, either in python or outside:
`import os`
`os.environ['MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR'] = '0'`

This does help with the problem, although the algorithm will sometimes still converge on predicting all samples with the same values in the end.
Is there anything new about this problem?
no，still can't solve this.

I tried setting the environment variable MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR = 0 but had no luck. I am still getting the same value for predictions. Also tried setting it to 1 and then back to 0, but I still get the same problem. I read the documentation for mxnet; The variable is by default set to 0. [Link](http://mxnet.io/how_to/env_var.html) 

I think there is some problem with the way I am creating the network or maybe with the input data that I am feeding to the network.
Can 'relu' activation function be not used for linear regression? because I get Nan while training when I use it.

I had similar experiences with relu and softrelu as well. It did help to not have any activation function between the final layer (with a single node) and the previous fully connected layer. 
 
I was able to train an inception v3 based neural net using a linear regression output and it did quite well for around 100 epochs but then it also started to produce the same prediction for all samples.

I suppose I can only put the continous variable into categories and fit the models. Hope this will be fixed in the future.
How do I get that change into my MXNet installation?
copy file python/mxnet/optimizer.py into `lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.9.5-py2.7.egg/mxnet`

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py
Do you mean another file?

@zackchase thanks for reviewing this. Pushed updates to address your comments.

@piiswrong You said not building with GPU enabled opencv is a _temporary_ solution; is there an improvement being planned in the future? GPU-enabled opencv is useful for my setting and myself and my colleagues also use docker containers which means the "first time" can be rather frequent, making this very slow startup somewhat painful. (I'll add that I'm currently using 0.9.4)

can you please add a little bit context here? do you want to test all the installation on travis? how many time will it cost? my concern is that our travis testing is pretty slow so we'd like not to add heavy tasks to it.
Try  changing the number of epochs to 50

Compiling for the 980 Ti architecture should solve your problem. Change config.mk line
-gencode arch=compute_50,code=sm_50
to
-gencode arch=compute_52,code=sm_52

with this setting you shouldn't have to set __launch_bounds().

List of all compute capabilities can be found on this Wikipedia page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CUDA
I submitted this PR to https://github.com/eric-haibin-lin/mxnet/pull/31 for sparse tensor development. Please do not merge this PR into dmlc/master.
Could be a problem with NDArrayIter. Does this also happen with ImageRecordIter?

@mli yes, sure.

There are two tasks that I've added to Travis as shown in the .travis.yml file:

1. installation_packaged_test

- Tests instructions for installing MXNet via either **1) virtualenv 2) pip**
- Runs a simple Python sanity test (create NDArray)
- Takes 2 minutes

2. installation_source_test

- Tests instructions for installing MXNet from **source**
- Runs a simple Python sanity test (create NDArray)
- Takes 16 minutes
- Needed to be put in a second task because it needs a clean environment

A successful run can be viewed here: https://travis-ci.org/lxn2/mxnet/builds/231756599

We did consider that it might cause Travis runs to be slower too, but testing installation instructions was high priority for v0.10 release and that's why we committed time to it. We're already covering installation instructions on Linux via Jenkins.

Some of the contents are more appropriate for a tutorial than a index page.
For example defining print_shape is not necessary. It is enough to directly state the shape of symbols in comment. >>> and out format is not necessary.

Also its not necessary to define value for all the constants. Use them directly.
I took a quick look but it looks pretty preliminary. Have you verified that its actually working?
Thanks. I had the same gut feeling but I wasn't sure, so I opted for the more verbose. I'm taking those out and will update s3.

from .ndarray import abs as ABS

Perhaps I can add to the following file to check whether the install.md guide has changed. If it has changed, we run the task. If not, we skip? Although I notice we've disabled this check...
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/travis/is_core_changed.sh

Another option can be to run this task only as a part of **nightly tests** on Travis. Thoughts?

Nope, I was hinted on new additions to Github and reacted on that. So you could be totally correct on this.
We're going to benchmark Torch7, Caffe and the MXnet in the coming weeks, and then we would've found out. Torch7 and Caffe are full ports for sure, so I assumed MXnet would too - it would explain the lack of build-instructions.

The good part is that you can choose to integrate it gradually, or wait until it's finished.

i think pair is needed. keys[i] stores the key for values[i]. if you sorted the keys into temp_keys, temp_keys[i] is no longer the key for the values[i]. 

i'm going to close the pr, please feel free to reopen it.

@madjam please try and avoid non-ascii unicode characters, as they cause build errors in making docs, such as the apostrophe and double quotes in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6232/files#diff-5e8a61de7d079049c8ba967135d05573R3.

OK just checked that a similar time factor (this time around *1.8 time in Module compared with Feedforward) appears also when using ImageRecordIter
in a toy example, this time using LeNet and cifar10 rec files as prepared in the image-classification demo
this is the code:
`import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from symbols import lenet as nettt
import sys
import time

print ('started ' + time.strftime('%x %X'))
startedd = time.time()

target_dim = 256

batcher = 64*8


epox=500;

use_module_on_your_own_risk=False#False#True

train= mx.io.ImageRecordIter(path_imgrec ='data\cifar10_train.rec',batch_size=batcher,data_shape=(3,28,28),shuffle=True)
val= mx.io.ImageRecordIter(path_imgrec ='data\cifar10_val.rec',batch_size=batcher,data_shape=(3,28,28))

da_net = nettt.get_symbol(num_classes=10)

devices = mx.gpu()

import logging

logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

batch_end_callbacks = [mx.callback.log_train_metric(50)]


if not use_module_on_your_own_risk:

    model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx=devices,
        symbol = da_net,       # network structure
        num_epoch = epox,     # number of  passes for training
        learning_rate = 0.0001,
        wd=1e-5,
        #initializer = mx.init.Normal(),
        initializer = mx.init.Xavier(rnd_type='gaussian', factor_type="in", magnitude=2),
        optimizer='adam'
    )
    model.fit(
        X=train,       # training data
        eval_data=val, # validation data
        eval_metric='acc',#.metric.Accuracy,
        batch_end_callback = batch_end_callbacks,
    )


else:
    model = mx.mod.Module(context = devices, symbol = da_net)

    ##train
    model.fit(train_data=train, eval_data =val ,eval_metric='acc', num_epoch=epox,batch_end_callback =batch_end_callbacks, optimizer='adam',optimizer_params={'learning_rate':0.0001,'wd':1e-5},initializer = mx.init.Xavier(rnd_type='gaussian', factor_type="in", magnitude=2))

finishedd= time.time()
print ('finished ' + time.strftime('%x %X') )
print ('sex:' + str(finishedd - startedd) )`

I don't see this when I compile on my system. The #ifdef in
https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/1d633cbf0bf5b13196cfbd95e6666df3c5f4a8a7/mshadow/half2.h#L11
Should insert __device__ into source code. Are some of the conditions of the #ifdef not met?

@starimpact Thanks for offering help. I have reproduced the problem using your python script. I roughly took a look at the backend binding flow for setting up using grad_req, it doesn't look like there are obvious bugs. Could you try to simplify the script by reducing the number of operators as much as possible so long as the issue is reproducible? It will greatly help me debug in the backend using a simple python script. I also asked @kevinthesun to help since he has more experience in frontend.
Can you provide a code snippet and std output? If you are talking about the API `SoftmaxOutput`, the forward pass should give you the probabilities.

@reminisce ok, I will try to give you a simplified one.
And, I suggest you have a look the v0.8.0 which is ok for this code to do a comparison.
@kevinthesun 
when:
```python
elif False and name=='proxy_yM':
```
will:
```
grad Z_weight: 6.7
```
when:
```python
elif True and name=='proxy_yM':
```
will:
```
grad Z_weight: -0.05
```

another interest discovery is that, when you set ```featdim < 3```, the problem is gone, but still exists when ```featdim>=3```

the simplified reproduction code:
```python
def init_args(args):
  initializer = mx.init.Normal()
  for key in args:
    arr = args[key]
    if key.endswith('_weight'):
      initializer(mx.init.InitDesc(key), arr)
#      initializer(key, arr)
    if key.endswith('_bias'):
      arr[:] = 0.0
    if key.endswith('_gamma'):
      arr[:] = 1.0
    if key.endswith('_beta'):
      arr[:] = 0.0
    if key.endswith('_init_c'):
      arr[:] = 0.0
    if key.endswith('_init_h'):
      arr[:] = 0.0

featdim = 3 #when featdim=2, the grad of proxy_Z_weight is not changed.
def create_reid4_net(batch_size, proxy_num):
  one_feat = mx.sym.Variable('data')
  one_proxy_yM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_yM')
  proxy_Z = mx.sym.Variable(name='proxy_Z_weight',
                       shape=(proxy_num, featdim), dtype=np.float32)
  one_proxy_ZM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_ZM')

  tzM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_ZM, shape=(-1,))
  z = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(one_feat, proxy_Z)
  z = mx.sym.abs(z)
  z = mx.sym.sum_axis(z, axis=1)

  tyM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_yM, shape=(-1, 1))
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(tyM, proxy_Z)
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.sum_axis(one_proxy_y, axis=0)
  one_feat = mx.sym.Reshape(one_feat, shape=(-1,))
  y = one_feat - one_proxy_y
  y = mx.sym.abs(y)
  y = mx.sym.sum(y)

  z_y = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(z, y)
  one_proxy_nca = mx.sym.sum(z_y * tzM)

  reid_net = one_proxy_nca
  reid_net = mx.sym.MakeLoss(reid_net, name='proxy_nca_loss')

  return reid_net

def get_params(sym, ctx, data_shape, label_shape):
  arg_names = sym.list_arguments()
  print arg_names
  arg_shapes, _, _ = sym.infer_shape(data=data_shape,
                                      **label_shape)

  arg_params = {}
  update_params = {}
  grad_req = {}
  grad_params = {}
  for name, shape in zip(arg_names, arg_shapes):
    arg_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    if name.endswith('weight') or name.endswith('bias') or \
        name.endswith('gamma') or name.endswith('beta'):
      update_params[name] = arg_params[name]
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    elif False and name=='proxy_yM':
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)

  init_args(arg_params)
  return arg_params, grad_req, grad_params

def test4():
  ctx = mx.gpu(0)
  batchsize = 1
  proxy_num = 10
  yM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  ZM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  data_shape = (batchsize, featdim)
  label_shape = {'proxy_yM':yM_shape, 'proxy_ZM':ZM_shape}

  inputypes = {'data':np.float32, 'proxy_yM':np.float32,
               'proxy_ZM':np.float32}

  net = create_reid4_net(batchsize, proxy_num)
  argt, _, auxt = net.infer_type(**inputypes)
  arg_params, grad_req, grad_params = get_params(net, ctx, data_shape, label_shape)
  executor = net.bind(ctx, arg_params, args_grad=grad_params, grad_req=grad_req)

  grad_dict = executor.grad_dict
  arg_dict = executor.arg_dict
  arg_dict['data'][:] = np.asarray(range(np.prod(data_shape)), dtype=np.float32).reshape(data_shape)/np.prod(data_shape)
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][:] = 0
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][0, 1] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][:] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][0, 1] = 0


  executor.forward(True)
  executor.backward()

  print 'output:', executor.outputs[0].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'data mean:', arg_dict['data'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'Z_weight:', arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'grad Z_weight:', grad_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()

if __name__=='__main__':
  test4()
```

This is too big for an example.
2-by-2 x 2 by 2 is enough.

Update: MKL 2017 Update 3 is out, dnnAlgorithmPoolingAvgIncludePadding is added in this release.
Also I found the cause of the crash when training my model resides in dropout-inl.h, where the MKL+OpenMP optimized path does not work in GPU context. Modifying the code to use the default path  fixes the crash.
@piiswrong  I wanted to provide an example for the 3d arrays as 1d and 2d dot products are trivial. Please let me know if this doesn't add much value and I can switch back to the 2d arrays.

the problem is relevant to the variable size of ```featdim```, so maybe it should be the backend problem.
@reminisce
Thanks for your reply. But it is no use to increase the epoch number. The results do not change much.

@starimpact Even when featdim=2, if you run test4() twice in the main function,
```python
if __name__ == '__main__':
    test4()
    test4()
```

the grad Z_weight are different from run to run. Looks like a result from some random initialization...

@reminisce this is because the initialization of weight_Z is random. you can fix it a constant value.
such as, add the following code after the ```arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][0, 1] = 0```:
```python
arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'][:] = np.ones(arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].shape)
```

the whole code is:
```python
featdim = 3
def create_reid4_net(batch_size, proxy_num):
  one_feat = mx.sym.Variable('data')
  one_proxy_yM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_yM')
  proxy_Z = mx.sym.Variable(name='proxy_Z_weight',
                       shape=(proxy_num, featdim), dtype=np.float32)
  one_proxy_ZM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_ZM')

  tzM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_ZM, shape=(-1,))
  z = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(one_feat, proxy_Z)
  z = mx.sym.abs(z)
  z = mx.sym.sum_axis(z, axis=1)

  tyM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_yM, shape=(-1, 1))
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(tyM, proxy_Z)
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.sum_axis(one_proxy_y, axis=0)
  one_feat = mx.sym.Reshape(one_feat, shape=(-1,))
  y = one_feat - one_proxy_y
  y = mx.sym.abs(y)
  y = mx.sym.sum(y)

  z_y = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(z, y)
  one_proxy_nca = mx.sym.sum(z_y * tzM)

  reid_net = one_proxy_nca
  reid_net = mx.sym.MakeLoss(reid_net, name='proxy_nca_loss')

  return reid_net

def get_params(sym, ctx, data_shape, label_shape):
  arg_names = sym.list_arguments()
  print arg_names
  arg_shapes, _, _ = sym.infer_shape(data=data_shape,
                                      **label_shape)

  arg_params = {}
  update_params = {}
  grad_req = {}
  grad_params = {}
  for name, shape in zip(arg_names, arg_shapes):
    arg_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    if name.endswith('weight') or name.endswith('bias') or \
        name.endswith('gamma') or name.endswith('beta'):
      update_params[name] = arg_params[name]
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    elif False and name=='proxy_yM':
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)

  return arg_params, grad_req, grad_params

def test4():
  ctx = mx.gpu(0)
  batchsize = 1
  proxy_num = 10
  yM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  ZM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  data_shape = (batchsize, featdim)
  label_shape = {'proxy_yM':yM_shape, 'proxy_ZM':ZM_shape}

  inputypes = {'data':np.float32, 'proxy_yM':np.float32,
               'proxy_ZM':np.float32}

  net = create_reid4_net(batchsize, proxy_num)
  argt, _, auxt = net.infer_type(**inputypes)
  arg_params, grad_req, grad_params = get_params(net, ctx, data_shape, label_shape)
  executor = net.bind(ctx, arg_params, args_grad=grad_params, grad_req=grad_req)

  grad_dict = executor.grad_dict
  arg_dict = executor.arg_dict
  arg_dict['data'][:] = np.asarray(range(np.prod(data_shape)), dtype=np.float32).reshape(data_shape)/np.prod(data_shape)
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][:] = 0
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][0, 1] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][:] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][0, 1] = 0
  arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'][:] = np.ones(arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].shape)

  executor.forward(True)
  executor.backward()

  print 'output:', executor.outputs[0].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'data mean:', arg_dict['data'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'Z_weight:', arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'grad Z_weight:', grad_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()

if __name__=='__main__':
  test4()
```

@reminisce 
wow, just let z_weight be a decimal array, the grad z weight will not change when ```featdim=2```:
```python
featdim = 3
def create_reid4_net(batch_size, proxy_num):
  one_feat = mx.sym.Variable('data')
  one_proxy_yM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_yM')
  proxy_Z = mx.sym.Variable(name='proxy_Z_weight',
                       shape=(proxy_num, featdim), dtype=np.float32)
  one_proxy_ZM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_ZM')

  tzM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_ZM, shape=(-1,))
  z = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(one_feat, proxy_Z)
  z = mx.sym.abs(z)
  z = mx.sym.sum_axis(z, axis=1)

  tyM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_yM, shape=(-1, 1))
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(tyM, proxy_Z)
  one_proxy_y = mx.sym.sum_axis(one_proxy_y, axis=0)
  one_feat = mx.sym.Reshape(one_feat, shape=(-1,))
  y = one_feat - one_proxy_y
  y = mx.sym.abs(y)
  y = mx.sym.sum(y)

  z_y = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(z, y)
  one_proxy_nca = mx.sym.sum(z_y * tzM)

  reid_net = one_proxy_nca
  reid_net = mx.sym.MakeLoss(reid_net, name='proxy_nca_loss')

  return reid_net

def get_params(sym, ctx, data_shape, label_shape):
  arg_names = sym.list_arguments()
  print arg_names
  arg_shapes, _, _ = sym.infer_shape(data=data_shape,
                                      **label_shape)

  arg_params = {}
  update_params = {}
  grad_req = {}
  grad_params = {}
  for name, shape in zip(arg_names, arg_shapes):
    arg_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    if name.endswith('weight') or name.endswith('bias') or \
        name.endswith('gamma') or name.endswith('beta'):
      update_params[name] = arg_params[name]
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)
    elif False and name=='proxy_yM':
      grad_req[name] = 'write'
      grad_params[name] = mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx)

  return arg_params, grad_req, grad_params

def test4():
  ctx = mx.gpu(0)
  batchsize = 1
  proxy_num = 10
  yM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  ZM_shape = (batchsize, proxy_num)
  data_shape = (batchsize, featdim)
  label_shape = {'proxy_yM':yM_shape, 'proxy_ZM':ZM_shape}

  inputypes = {'data':np.float32, 'proxy_yM':np.float32,
               'proxy_ZM':np.float32}

  net = create_reid4_net(batchsize, proxy_num)
  argt, _, auxt = net.infer_type(**inputypes)
  arg_params, grad_req, grad_params = get_params(net, ctx, data_shape, label_shape)
  executor = net.bind(ctx, arg_params, args_grad=grad_params, grad_req=grad_req)

  grad_dict = executor.grad_dict
  arg_dict = executor.arg_dict
  arg_dict['data'][:] = np.asarray(range(np.prod(data_shape)), dtype=np.float32).reshape(data_shape)/np.prod(data_shape)
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][:] = 0
  arg_dict['proxy_yM'][0, 1] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][:] = 1
  arg_dict['proxy_ZM'][0, 1] = 0
  zshape = arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].shape
  zdata = np.asarray(range(np.prod(zshape)), dtype=np.float32)/np.prod(zshape)
  arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'][:] = zdata.reshape(zshape)

  executor.forward(True)
  executor.backward()

  print 'output:', executor.outputs[0].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'data mean:', arg_dict['data'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'Z_weight:', arg_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()
  print 'grad Z_weight:', grad_dict['proxy_Z_weight'].asnumpy().mean()

if __name__=='__main__':
  test4()
```

Could you add a remark in these doc pages about the difference and when you should use the `mx.sym.RNN` _symbol_ vs. the rnn _module_? My best guess is the symbol is for specific RNN layers that are GPU optimized whereas the module is a more general interface/set of tools, but is perhaps less optimized.
